item.title: Word of the Day: circumspect
item.description: This word has appeared in 92 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Trump Attacks Fed Governors Ahead of Key Interest Rate Meeting
item.description: During a speech in Pennsylvania focused on the economy, President Trump criticized the Fed chair, Jerome Powell, and four other members. The attack came as the Fed prepares to reveal new interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Paik

media:content.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump called Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, a “bad head of the Fed” during a speech in Pennsylvania on Tuesday.

item.title: Late Night Doesn’t Want to Sweat at the Airport
item.description: Ronny Chieng dissed new fitness plans from the Trump administration for travelers in American airports: “We can’t even walk to the gate. They had to invent floors that walk for us.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)

item.title: Trump Picked This Fight With Maduro. He Can’t Back Down.
item.description: If the Trump administration allows Nicolás Maduro to endure, it would signal that a criminal dictatorship masquerading as a state can stare down the United States and win.
item.dc:creator: Ricardo Hausmann and Jose Morales-Arilla
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado and the presidential candidate Edmundo González at a rally in Caracas, Venezuela, in July 2024.

item.title: Propósito 2026: informarse y no abrumarse
item.description: ¿Tienes alguna estrategia para hacer frente a la actualidad y a las noticias? Queremos conocerla.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold

item.title: Rod Paige, Education Secretary Who Defended ‘No Child Left Behind,’ Dies at 92
item.description: He was both the first Black person and the first educator to hold the cabinet position, but resigned amid discord over George W. Bush’s No Child Left Behind.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden

media:content.media:credit: Brooks Kraft/Corbis, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Rod Paige, the education secretary, in Nashville in 2004.

item.title: Los 299.171 kilómetros de caminos que llevan a Roma, en un mapa
item.description: Un atlas digital de las carreteras y veredas de la antigua ciudad italiana revela una red viaria más extensa de lo que se pensaba.
item.dc:creator: Franz Lidz

media:content.media:credit: Jonathan Corum/The New York Times

item.title: Taiwan Invokes National Security Law to Protect TSMC Trade Secrets
item.description: An executive left TSMC for Intel. Taiwan’s government says that could threaten its national security.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin and Xinyun Wu

media:content.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The authorities in Taiwan are taking a stronger hand in protecting the prized technology of the chip maker TSMC.

item.title: Chip Company Plotted to Send Technology to China, Ex-C.E.O. Says
item.description: The former chief executive of Nexperia, a Dutch chipmaker, said Dutch officials had known for years that the company’s Chinese owner sought to move its technology to China.
item.dc:creator: Mara Hvistendahl and Joy Dong

media:content.media:credit: Fabian Bimmer/Reuters
media:content.media:description: On a production line of the Dutch semiconductor company Nexperia in Hamburg, Germany, last year. Dutch officials seized the company in September.

item.title: Corrections: Dec. 10, 2025
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Dec. 10, 2025.

item.title: Quote of the Day: For One ICE Detainee, Severe Pain and Neglect
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, December 10, 2025.

item.title: Trump’s Speech on Economy Veers Into an Anti-Immigrant Tirade
item.description: President Trump vacillated between demonizing immigrants and assuring a crowd of his supporters that life was better than ever under his administration.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump spoke to his supporters at the Mount Airy Casino Resort in Mount Pocono, Pa., on Tuesday.

item.title: Machado y su Nobel de la Paz generan críticas en Oslo a horas de la premiación
item.description: Los múltiples guiños al presidente Trump hacen que muchos duden sobre si la política venezolana merece esa distinción.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky and Henrik Pryser Libell

media:content.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: La líder opositora María Corina Machado en su despacho, en Caracas, el año pasado.

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Dec. 10, 2025
item.description: Kareem Ayas makes a break for it.
item.dc:creator: Sam Corbin

item.title: Trump Administration Withdraws Plan to Overhaul Homeless Aid
item.description: The abrupt decision to revise the plan added new uncertainty and possible delays into the government’s distribution of $3.9 billion in homelessness relief.
item.dc:creator: Jason DeParle

media:content.media:credit: Aaron Wojack for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A homeless camp outside Suisun City, Calif., last month.

item.title: Democrats Say Hegseth Balked at Call for Full Video of Boat Strike
item.description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth briefed congressional leaders on Tuesday about the monthslong military campaign targeting people suspected of being drug traffickers at sea.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth at the Capitol on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump Revives Attacks on Fed Members Before Interest Rate Decision
item.description: Without evidence, the president claimed that some Fed governors might have been appointed using an autopen.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm

media:content.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump called Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, a “bad head of the Fed” during a speech in Pennsylvania on Tuesday.

item.title: This Arkansas City Shows How to Slash Emissions and Save Money, Too
item.description: In the Ozarks, the growing college town of Fayetteville, Ark., is using clean energy to power city facilities and embracing nature-based solutions to climate threats.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley and Melyssa St. Michael

media:content.media:credit: Melyssa St. Michael for The New York Times

item.title: Inside the Pentagon’s Scramble to Deal With Boat Strike Survivors
item.description: Officials initially weighed sending survivors of U.S. attacks on boats suspected of drug smuggling to a notorious prison in El Salvador, to keep them away from American courts.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave, Edward Wong and Maria Abi-Habib
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )

media:content.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Recent news reports on strike orders given by Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth have raised questions of potential war crimes.

item.title: Wyoming Cowboys Are Breaking Down Barriers, Literally
item.description: GPS collars on cattle are letting ranchers remove fences in the West. That’s good for wildlife and for the land.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Dzombak and Will Warasila

media:content.media:credit: Will Warasila for The New York Times

item.title: Utah Tries Relocating Beavers to Save Them, and Remake the Landscape
item.description: Their dams cause floods, and that gets them in trouble with humans. But in the right place, more water can be a big help.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn and Kim Raff

media:content.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times

item.title: Ranchers in South Dakota Turn to Prescribed Burns to Treat Their Land
item.description: A “green glacier” of trees is steadily taking over native grasslands. Landowners are banding together to treat the problem with fire.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey

item.title: Not All Drilling in Texas Is About Oil
item.description: The state has become a hub of innovation for creating electricity using geothermal power. Just don’t call it renewable.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman and Kaylee Greenlee for The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Kaylee Greenlee for The New York Times

item.title: Canada’s Ambassador to U.S., Who Also Led Trade Talks, to Leave Post
item.description: Kirsten Hillman, who came to Washington during the first Trump administration, had already extended her tenure once.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen

media:content.media:credit: Justin Tang/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Kirsten Hillman did not specify a date for the end of her tenure but said that after she leaves, she will still be available to Canada’s negotiators.

item.title: The Battle for Warner Bros. Discovery
item.description: Nicole Sperling, a Times reporter who covers Hollywood and the streaming revolution, breaks down the competing bids from Netflix and Paramount to buy Warner Bros. Discovery.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling, Edward Vega, Laura Salaberry, Jon Hazell and Chris Orr

item.title: FDA Expands Covid Vaccine Inquiry to Adult Deaths
item.description: The agency claimed that 10 children’s deaths were linked to the shots, although it did not release evidence to support the assertions.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett

media:content.media:credit: Charity Rachelle for The New York Times

item.title: Trump Calls Europe ‘Decaying’ and ‘Weak’
item.description: President Trump criticized his European counterparts over their defense and Ukraine policies during an interview with Politico. The president also suggested that it was time for President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine to compromise in the cease-fire talks.
item.dc:creator: Chevaz Clarke

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and other European leaders during a meeting at the White House earlier this year.

item.title: Ukraine Could Be ‘Ready for Elections,’ Zelensky Says
item.description: The Ukrainian president told reporters that a vote could be held in 60 to 90 days if the country received security protections from the United States.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine speaking at the White House in Washington, D.C., in October.

item.title: Democrat Eileen Higgins Wins Miami Runoff Election to Become City’s First Female Mayor
item.description: Eileen Higgins, a former Miami-Dade County commissioner, will also be the city’s first female mayor and the first non-Hispanic mayor since the 1990s.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei

media:content.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Eileen Higgins in Miami in November.

item.title: México busca llegar a un acuerdo con Trump en el tema del agua
item.description: El presidente de EE. UU. amenazó con imponer aranceles a las importaciones mexicanas por una disputa sobre el agua. La presidenta de México, Claudia Sheinbaum, busca negociar un acuerdo.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Jack Nicas

media:content.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Claudia Sheinbaum dijo a los periodistas el martes que encontraría una solución “que no ponga en riesgo evidentemente a la población y a la producción agrícola en México, pero que también podamos ayudar a los Estados Unidos” .

item.title: Trump Says Americans Are Doing Great, Even as Views on the Economy Sour
item.description: President Trump’s speech in Pennsylvania was meant to alleviate concerns about affordability. But he kept wandering off script and dwelling on his favorite targets, like immigration.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump delivering remarks on the economy at the Mount Airy Casino Resort in Mount Pocono, Pa., on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. Plans to Scrutinize Foreign Tourists’ Social Media History
item.description: Even visitors from countries like Britain and France, whose citizens don’t need visas, would have to share five years’ worth of social media.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung

media:content.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Visitors from countries in the visa-waiver program would also be required to share a range of other information, including email addresses from the last decade.

item.title: Special End-of-Year 2025 News Quiz for Students
item.description: See what you remember about this extraordinary year by taking our special 2025 news quiz.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Engle

media:content.media:credit: Clockwise from bottom left: Chris Pizzello/Associated Press; Andrew Medichini/Associated Press; Jamie Kelter Davis; Ashley Landis/Associated Press; Ye Fan

item.title: Prosecutors Release Body Camera Footage of Luigi Mangione’s Arrest
item.description: The footage shows officers confronting Luigi Mangione at a McDonald’s in Altoona, Pa. Lawyers for Mr. Mangione, who is accused of killing the former C.E.O. of UnitedHealthcare, argued that the evidence recovered at his arrest should not be admitted into trial, as it was obtained without a warrant.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Leventhal

item.title: Trump’s Nvidia Chip Deal Reverses Decades of Technology Restrictions
item.description: President Trump’s decision to allow Nvidia to sell its chips to China has raised questions about whether he is prioritizing short-term economic gain over long-term American security interests.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger

media:content.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump with Jensen Huang, the chief executive of Nvidia, at the White House in April.

item.title: Seattle’s Plans for a Pride Match at World Cup Infuriates Iran and Egypt
item.description: The two countries, which criminalize homosexuality and impose severe punishments for it, were picked to play on a day celebrating L.G.B.T.Q. communities.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi

media:content.media:credit: Kevin Dietsch/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Iran learned its group at the FIFA World Cup draw last week in Washington, D.C.

item.title: For Real, a Natural History of Misinformation
item.description: It’s not just humans who suffer from leading one another astray. So do fish, flies and even bacteria.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer

media:content.media:credit: Rob Stewart/Image Bank Film, via Getty Images

item.title: At State Dept., a Typeface Falls Victim in the War Against Woke
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio called the Biden-era move to the sans serif typeface “wasteful,” casting the return to Times New Roman as part of a push to stamp out diversity efforts.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Hamed Aleaziz

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio at the White House last month.

item.title: Bird Flu Is Suspected After Vulture Carcasses Sat Rotting Outside Ohio School
item.description: The birds lingered for days at a Catholic school near Cincinnati as agencies haggled over who was responsible for removing them. Officials said the public health risk was low.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor

item.title: Oregon and Washington Face Flooding From Atmospheric River
item.description: Even for a region used to heavy rain, this week’s system has forecasters on edge. The heaviest rain is expected into Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Amy Graff

media:content.media:credit: David Ryder/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Floodwaters crept close to a home in Fall City, Wash., on Tuesday.

item.title: Stephen Miller’s Stock Sale Raises Questions, Ethics Experts Say
item.description: Mr. Miller, one of President Trump’s top advisers, sold shares in the mining company MP Materials following a lucrative deal between the company and the government.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Stephen Miller, one of the president’s top advisers, sold shares of a mining company after it had begun negotiations with the government, raising concerns among ethics experts.

item.title: Were Kylie Jenner and Timothée Chalamet’s Matching ‘Marty Supreme’ Looks Style or Strategy?
item.description: Timothée Chalamet and Kylie Jenner wore matching orange outfits at a “Marty Supreme” premiere. Was it a ’90s throwback or an attempt to quiet the rumors?
item.dc:creator: Emily Lang

media:content.media:credit: Frederic J. Brown/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Timothée Chalamet and Kylie Jenner wore matching outfits at the Los Angeles premiere of “Marty Supreme,” a film that Mr. Chalamet produced and starred in.

item.title: GOP Senators Will Counter Democrats’ Bid to Preserve Health Care Subsidies
item.description: Senate Republicans plan to offer a proposal that would create a new payment for people with bare-bones health coverage, clashing with Democrats who are pressing for an extension of existing tax credits.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Senator John Thune, the South Dakota Republican and majority leader, at the Capitol on Tuesday.

item.title: End of Major Corruption Case Embarrasses N.Y. Cannabis Regulators
item.description: A case against the Long Island-based cannabis company Omnium Health was halted on the eve of trial. A judge on Tuesday held off on dropping the matter.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Southall

media:content.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Omnium Health, in Hauppauge, N.Y., has been the focus of a major state corruption investigation.

item.title: Vistas Painted by Georgia O’Keeffe Protected by Conservation Plan
item.description: The plan will protect 6,000 acres of land in northern New Mexico, and the state is giving more than $900,000 toward the effort.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor

item.title: Nobel Peace Prize for Venezuela’s María Corina Machado Draws Criticism
item.description: María Corina Machado is being honored for her push for democracy even as she backs President Trump’s military buildup and aggressive campaign against Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky and Henrik Pryser Libell

media:content.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The opposition leader María Corina Machado in her office in Caracas last year.

item.title: Storm System Causes Flooding in the Pacific Northwest
item.description: The Snoqualmie River and the Chehalis River flooded roads and neighborhoods in Washington after a storm system brought heavy rain to the Pacific Northwest.

media:content.media:credit: David Ryder/Reuters
media:content.media:description: The Snoqualmie River flooded in Fall City, Wash., on Tuesday.

item.title: Jubilant Sykes, Celebrated Opera Singer, Is Stabbed to Death
item.description: After the police found the Grammy-nominated performer in his home with fatal wounds, his son was taken into custody, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor

media:content.media:credit: Hiroyuki Ito for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Jubilant Sykes performing as the Celebrant in “Mass,” by Leonard Bernstein, at Carnegie Hall in 2008.

item.title: After Trump Threatens Tariffs, Mexico Seeks a Deal on Water
item.description: President Trump threatened 5 percent tariffs on Mexican imports over a water dispute. Mexico’s president, Claudia Sheinbaum, wants an agreement instead.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Jack Nicas

media:content.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Claudia Sheinbaum told reporters on Tuesday that she would find a solution “that does not put the population and agricultural production in Mexico at risk, but that can also help the United States.”

item.title: Trump Pressures Ukraine
item.description: Also, the Supreme Court considers campaign finance limits. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and other European leaders at the White House in August.
